This game has a lot of what I want and misses a few things that I always like to have.  It is a great town builder, you get multiply chances to build towns that trade with each other and help your towns/cities thrive as you take what each isle has and trade it to those islands that are lacking that product.  You never find that isle that has everything you want, so you have to make sure you have trade routes set up; which means you have to protect your ships that go out to sea from pirates and enemy factions.  

The part I am not overly fond of is that you can never build that huge spread out city.  The islands limited space means you have to be precise in your buildings in order to get everything you need to fit on an island; that usually means many changes and building relocation as you realize you no longer have the room for later buildings, or that you have to make more houses to get to the upgrades that you need to make more building on a specific isle.  I love keeping track of the production lines and what I need to trade where, but honestly I would love to have one isle that I could spread things out a bit more as i am not a big fan of clustering everything so tightly together to make rooms for items i needed later in the game.

Anno 1800 is one of the best and by far the highest quality city builder/management games out there. Set in a beautiful 19th century setting with light steampunk elements, it's absolutely one of my favorite historical settings. It lets you play in various locations. The base game has both an Old World and New World, where you have to create intercontinental trade routes and logistics systems. You build some genuine complex production chains for a city builder/management game.

This does lead to the main negative. All these complicated logistics are difficult to follow when you have really complex settlements, as the menus can be hard to understand. But luckily the game isn't too punishing, and a production chain not running smoothly won't immediately bankrupt you.

The game also has a full campaign/story mode, but I personally stick to sandbox because that‚Äôs where the game really shines for me. altought even in sandbox there a verious missions you can do. On top of that, there are four seasons of DLC that add even more content, extra production chains, new mechanics, and whole new regions like the Arctic and an Africa-inspired map.

Overall, Anno 1800 is one of the great city-builder/management games of all time.
If you love the setting and want a polished, deep, and beautiful strategy game, it‚Äôs absolutely worth trying.

Anno 1800 takes players to the dawn of the Industrial Age, combining the classic city-building charm of earlier Anno games with deep economic systems, trade, and diplomacy. You start with a small farming settlement and grow it into a sprawling industrial empire ‚Äî balancing labor, pollution, trade routes, and the happiness of your citizens.

The core gameplay revolves around urban planning, production chains, and resource management. Every product depends on others ‚Äî for instance, soap requires tallow, which comes from pigs, which in turn need grain farms.

You‚Äôll also manage:

Multiple islands to access different resources

Trade routes across the Old and New Worlds

Naval combat and exploration

Diplomacy with AI factions

The pacing is satisfying: early hours focus on agriculture and logistics, while later stages introduce electricity, skyscrapers, and tourism.

üß≠ Strengths

‚úÖ Stunning visuals ‚Äì Cities feel alive, with detailed animations and vibrant atmospheres.
‚úÖ Deep economic simulation ‚Äì Complex production chains make optimization rewarding.
‚úÖ Replayability ‚Äì Procedurally generated maps and different strategies.
‚úÖ Expansions & DLC ‚Äì The ‚ÄúSeason Passes‚Äù add tons of content like the Arctic, Africa, and skyscraper construction.
‚úÖ Music & ambiance ‚Äì A rich orchestral score that perfectly fits the industrial tone.

‚öñÔ∏è Weaknesses

‚ùå Steep learning curve ‚Äì Managing multiple islands and supply lines can overwhelm newcomers.
‚ùå Performance issues ‚Äì Large cities can strain even powerful PCs.
‚ùå DLC model ‚Äì Some players find the amount of paid DLC excessive.
‚ùå Limited combat depth ‚Äì Naval battles feel secondary compared to the economic gameplay.

üåç Verdict

Anno 1800 is one of the best city-building games ever made ‚Äî a beautiful, complex, and endlessly rewarding simulation of the Industrial Revolution. It demands patience and planning, but the payoff is immense when you watch your cities bustle with life.

‚≠ê Score: 9/10

This game has too much happening that needs to be micromanaged, the economy is brutal, and I cba to look up optimal building placement when I just want to build something that looks nice. I played the game vanilla with no DLC since I'm new to the franchise and wanted to learn. 

I feel punished for producing more resources than I need when trying to plan for a future population by penalising my economy since my own pop aren't buying enough of it, which leads to two issues. First, they trade for little and only sporadically passively with the AI and if I set up trade routes to those buying, there's good chance it will later not be wanted anymore. Second, when I do need more resources, I normally find out when I suddenly have less pop since, without telling me that I need to build more, I get penalised again since the people are unhappy and moving out reducing pop and leaving buildings empty of workers. 
The graphs for pop and resource balance are wholly unexplained and as a new player to the franchise make no sense. I'm not sure if it's telling me I can support more pop or not, or if I'm overproducing/underproducing resources. My economy is either minorly stable or massively fluctuating when I unlock the next tier and begin upgrading and then I have the whole balancing act again. There's an interesting mechanic for the time it takes for buildings to produce outputs which was the only enjoyable thing I liked to manage. 

Then there's multi island + world management where it all becomes neglected for ages while I try sorting one of them out. 

If you want to micro manage and look up optimal ways of layout building this might be the game for you. There is little QOL to help manage it all. I also hate that  buildings are hidden+locked until I tier up, then I need to rearrange everything each time.
